page.title: 04Wivelsfield - Ecology (1)
page.content:
{Woodland Ecology - Abbotsleigh Estate In 1957 the natural woodland was cut down and replanted with Norway Spruce, Douglas Firs and Scotch Firs. Rides are left between the rows to protect the trees from gales and fire, which can also spread via rabbit holes and mole hills. There are some 50' Beech trees which were planted in 1930.
The trees are cut to order at the saw mill in the wood. The bark is shredded to be used as a mulch. Fir tops are supplied to Hickstead for show jumping fences.The wood is used for pulp, garden fences and posts.
Fox and mink have to be kept down by shooting but rabbits are in reasonable numbers and do not cause a problem. Most wildlife does not like this type of woodland.
